channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Stablecoin Firm Circle’s IPO Raises $1.1 Billion in Upsized Deal
item.description: Circle Internet Group Inc. and some of its shareholders raised nearly $1.1 billion in an upsized initial public offering that was priced above a marketed range, in a sign that stablecoin issuers are winning greater acceptance.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The Circle logo arranged on a smartphone in New York, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 12, 2025. Circle Internet Financial Ltd.'s USDC stablecoin has gained back all of the market value it lost after the collapse in crypto prices following the failure of FTX. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

item.title: Enterprise Products Says US Set to Deny Its China Ethane Export License
item.description: Enterprise Products Partners LP received a notice saying the US intends to deny licenses for three proposed cargoes of ethane heading to China as the Trump administration doubles down on security for exports to the country.
item.dc:creator: Emma Sanchez

media:content.media:description: A gas processing facility operated by Enterprise Products Partners LP stands in Yscloskey, Louisiana, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2010. Enterprise Products Partners LP, the largest U.S. pipeline operator, agreed to buy Enterprise GP Holdings LP for more than $8 billion, combining two of the partnerships founded by the late billionaire Dan Duncan.

item.title: Japanese Bonds Back on Stage With Another Sale of Longer Debt
item.description: Japan’s sovereign debt is back in the spotlight as the government prepares for another sale of super-long-term bonds after dismal showings at recent auctions, as demand for the far-end of the curve sputters across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Hidenori Yamanaka

media:content.media:description: The Sunshine 60 building, top center, and other buildings in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Feb. 17.

item.title: F1 Academy’s Susie Wolff
item.description: Alex Rodriguez and Jason Kelly sit with Susie Wolff, the managing director of F1 Academy, about how she’s helping more female racers try to advance into the ranks of Formula One. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: 23andMe Judge Questions Limits for New Auction for Bankrupt Firm
item.description: The judge overseeing the bankruptcy of 23andMe questioned the limits proposed for a second auction that is designed to push bids higher than a current $256 million offer from Regeneron Pharmaceuticals for the genetic-testing firm.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church

media:content.media:description: Signage at 23andMe headquarters in Sunnyvale, California, U.S., on Wednesday, Jan. 27, 2021. Consumer DNA-testing company 23andMe Inc. is in talks to go public through a roughly $4 billion deal with VG Acquisition Corp., a special purpose acquisition company founded by billionaire Richard Branson, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.title: Aluminum Executives Balk at Trump’s Latest 50% Tariff Move
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s newly imposed 50% tariff on aluminum imports may be too much for consumers to accept and crush demand, industry executives warned.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: A worker, top right, uses a crane to move a roll of aluminium made from recycled material at the Novelis Inc. facility in Pindamonhangaba, Brazil, on Thursday, Nov. 5, 2015. Brazil produced 61.4 thousand tons of aluminium in September and 584 thousand so far in 2015, according to a report by the Brazil aluminium association.

item.title: Brazil Sells $2.75 Billion in Return to Global Debt Markets
item.description: Brazil sold $2.75 billion of dollar bonds, offering debt for the second time in less than six months as investors seeking to diversify away from the US fuel a rally in emerging-market assets.
item.dc:creator: Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Vinicius Andrade

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Brazil headquarters in Brasilia.

item.title: Emerging-Market Currencies Led by Korean Won Gain After US Data
item.description: Developing-market currencies extended gains Wednesday following the release of US data that stoked concerns over the state of the economy and heightened speculation that rate cuts are forthcoming.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Butler, Leda Alvim

media:content.media:description: The rising Kospi and Kosdaq indices displayed at the Korea Exchange in Seoul, on June 4.

item.title: Spain Makes First Payment in Lengthy Fight Over Renewable Energy
item.description: The Spanish government made its first payment as a result of an arbitration decision in 2021 around the country’s move to change investor incentives tied to renewable energy projects, following a number of lengthy legal battles between Spain and various creditors.
item.dc:creator: Irene Garcia Perez

media:content.media:description: Wind turbines and electricity power lines in Zaragoza, Spain, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Europe’s top renewable energy developer has focused the bulk of its investments on grid projects in the US, UK and other global markets — a business that has performed well. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: China In Wait and See Mode: Cameron Johnson
item.description: US-China trade talks do not appear to be progressing as President Trump said via social media, China's leader Xi Jinping is "extremely hard to a deal with." Tidalwave Solutions Senior Partner Cameron Johnson has more on the story. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks End Mixed After Choppy Session | Closing Bell
item.description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, David Gura, Emily Graffeo. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: GeoPark’s Shareholder Plan Creates Opening to Thwart Hostile Bid
item.description: Latin American oil and gas producer GeoPark looks to be making moves to defend itself form a hostile takeover after a rival energy firm took a large stake in the company.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Jaramillo, Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Bogota, Colombia, on Sunday, July 3, 2022. Dozens of Venezuelan opposition figures, who turned Colombia into their unofficial headquarters in recent years, say the election of Gustavo Petro as Colombia's first leftist president puts them at risk, and they plan to leave. Photographer: Nathalia Angarita/Bloomberg

item.title: Pres. Trump's Attack on DEI
item.description: Diversity Equity and Inclusion is back in spotlight with President Donald Trump's crack down on the policy. Bloomberg' news Shaquille Omari explains how the president's push to end DEI is reframing corporate America. Bloomberg's Shaquille Omari reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Hold Steady Despite Weak Data, Buoyed by Big Tech
item.description: US equities eked out a third straight session of gains on Wednesday as a rally in big technology stocks offset weak economic data on jobs and services.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Officials Target Columbia Accreditation Standards
item.description: The Education Department said Columbia University no longer appeared to meet accreditation standards after concluding that the school is in violation of anti-discrimination laws. Akayla Gardner reports on “Bloomberg The Close.”

item.title: Three of US’s Top Steel Suppliers Are Seeking Breaks on Tariffs
item.description: The US’s top steel providers are racing to win exemptions from Donald Trump’s steel tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Simone Iglesias, Mariana Durao

media:content.media:description: A worker cuts steel sheets at an auto parts manufacturer in San Luis Potosi, San Luis Potosi state, Mexico, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. US President Donald Trump's potential tariffs against Canada and Mexico will threaten production at automakers across North America and send record vehicle prices even higher.

item.title: Treasuries Rally as Weak Data Reinforce Fed Wagers: Markets Wrap
item.description: Treasuries rallied after weaker-than-expected economic data reinforced speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at least twice this year to prevent an economic recession.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: UBS Asset Management Says Japan Should Stop Issuing Long Bonds to Halt Selloff
item.description: A veteran portfolio manager has some advice for Japan: To calm volatility in the country’s government bond market, stop issuing debt with maturities above 30 years.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Start of the New Consumer Renaissance: NEA’s Bordetsky
item.description: Ann Bordetsky, NEA partner, says artificial intelligence will drive a new consumer tech renaissance and investors will find bigger returns from consumer AI than from enterprise. Bordetsky joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Waystar Celebrates One Year on The Nasdaq
item.description: One year ago, Waystar made its debut on the public market and it was one of 2024's largest deals, raising around $1 billion at the time. Waystar CEO Matt Hawkin said at the time, he was building a durable, high growth, AI powered business with the goal of simplifying healthcare payments. He speaks with Vonnie Quinn on how things went in the first year. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: HPE CEO on Reducing Expected Tariff Impact
item.description: HPE CEO Antonio Neri explains why the company has reduced the impact it expects to see from tariffs. Neri speaks about HPE earnings with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Blue Owl’s Clarke Says Investors Are Pushing Consolidation
item.description: James Clarke, head of institutional business at Blue Owl Capital, says, "there’s a lot going on that has been a massive sea change in the alternative space." with major credit firms squeezing out smaller players as investors look to consolidate relationships. He speaks with Bloomberg’s Dani Burger on the sidelines of the SuperReturn Conference in Berlin. (Corrects name of guest in headline) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Salesforce, Informatica Is Good for Permira, Co-CEO Says
item.description: Permira co-Managing Partner and co-CEO Brian Ruder explains why the $25 per share price that Salesforce is paying for Informatica is good for his investors. Ruder joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: KKR Quit Thames Bid After It Saw Little Upside to a Rescue
item.description: KKR & Co. withdrew its bid to invest £4 billion ($5.4 billion) in Thames Water when the US infrastructure giant realized there was little upside to a deal, according to people familiar with the deliberations.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha, Claire Ruckin, Giulia Morpurgo

media:content.media:description: Engineers' vans parked at the Thames Water South Woodford pumping station in London.

item.title: Tesla’s Full Self-Driving Factored in Fatal Crash
item.description: Video of a fatal Tesla crash from 2023 shows the role of what the carmaker calls Full Self-Driving, or FSD, played. Bloomberg’s Craig Trudell breaks down what happened and why it matters now, with Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Falls as Saudi Arabia Seeks More Major Production Hikes
item.description: Oil fell on signs Saudi Arabia wants another major production increase, raising expectations that a glut of crude will form this year.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Julia Fanzeres

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Wells Fargo CFO on Asset Cap Lift, Consumers, Deposits
item.description: Wells Fargo CFO Mike Santomassimo reacts to the bank being released from a Federal Reserve asset cap that has restricted its size for over seven years. Speaking on “Bloomberg The Close,” Santomassimo also discusses the state of consumer spending and Wells Fargo’s deposits business.

item.title: GlobalFoundries to Spend $16 Billion on US Production
item.description: Chipmaker GlobalFoundries plans to spend $16 billion to bolster production in New York and Vermont. GlobalFoundries CEO Tim Breen joins Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Reshapes DEI In Corporate America
item.description: President Donald Trump is attempting to reshape corporate America by cracking down on DEI initiatives. The Verna Myers Company Diversity Pioneer Vernā Myers explains the implications on these cuts on "Bloomberg Markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Rallies as Weak US Data Reinforce Bets on Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Gold rallied after weaker-than-expected US economic data reinforced speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at least twice this year.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan
